Award.AwardTitle: Engineering Ethics Training by Expert Witness Role Play

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops the science of teaching engineering ethics by engaging students as expert witnesses in a litigation role play experience. Standard pedagogies expose students to broad ethical dilemmas that they may encounter in their careers and provide valuable practice in ethical reasoning related to these problems. Expert witness role plays have the potential to expand on this base of knowledge to help students develop awareness and practical skills to deal with the ethical challenges of maintaining scientific objectivity as an expert witness in their specifica area of study.

The intellectual merit of this research comes from extending an anecdotally successful role play experience based on reconstructing a traffic crash by developing five complete expert witness role plays and evaluating the efficacy of this approach in two institutions using both formative and summative evaluation techniques. The broader impact of this work includes developing a framework to aid other educators in developing expert witness role plays on additional engineering expert topics and disseminating the result of this project on commonly used ethics web portals to incorporate expert witness role plays in their own classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the effectiveness of teaching engineering students professional ethics by having them role play as an engineering expert witness. The role play required them to analyze a case using their technical skills from their engineering education and present their findings as an expert witness. This approach enabled the students to experience the stress of explaining their findings to a non-technical audience, having their findings questioned, and being pushed to modify their results. Throughout the project, different engineering cases, presentation formats, and teaching techniques were used in order to refine the method. Across all of the approaches, students found the experience to be challenging and worthwhile. There were also changes in student’s efficacy and perspectives on the professional ethics of engineers. Students commented that they had never experienced anything like this before and that it should definitely be offered to other students. Educators using the approach also found the experience to be rewarding as it provides new perspectives on the student’s educational progress. The results and design of this approach have been presented at four conferences for engineering educators. One of the conferences focused mainly on K-12 science educators. The approach is highly adaptable to different engineering areas and levels of technical expertise. This approach shows promise across a wide range of fields as a unique mechanism for professional ethics education that ties in technical expertise and real world psychological experiences.

The project ran at two institutions to assess scalability and transportability. Together, the University of Tulsa and Dartmouth College developed, implemented, and assessed role play scenarios for teaching engineering ethics. At The University of Tulsa, the ethics training was conducted in a junior level mechanical engineering course on Machine Dynamics. The scenarios involved a traffic crash where the students played the role of an expert witness in determining possible causes of the crash such as projected vehicles speeds. At Dartmouth, this project supported the development of ethics modules that were integrated into an introductory project-based engineering. The modules are structured around role-play exercises that emphasize scenarios in energy.  Some of the module offering concerning the use of land for a proposed (hypothetical) solar energy development project. An additional case related to natural gas exploration was also developed. The exercises required the students to work in teams, each team representing a different side of a proposed engineering project. Students were required to consider a mixture of information from varying sources (some of which conflicted with their own incentive structure) and to use their engineering toolset to make an argument representative of their position. The case was litigated as a role-play exercise where each side presents their rationale for choosing a particular path forward. The outcome is decided by a group of students who are chosen to represent the so-called general public, but who also have their own incentive structure with the potential to bias their decision.

An output of the project is a recipe of key concepts that have been tried and tested at two institutions and two engineering disciplines. These ingredients are:

  • Technical Questions –the issues and questions that can be addressed by performing a technical engineering analysis. This enables the instructor to easily integrate the exercise into existing technical classes and tailor the experience to the engineering expertise of the instructor.
  • Ambiguity – the dataset should be incomplete to draw firm conclusions. Assumptions will need to be made and students will need to be asked technical questions but have imperfect data. Also, ranges of acceptable answers and articulating the reliability of a result is needed.
  • Diversion Data – The scenario should contain sensational data that may be used to evoke empathy to help students compare personal and professional ethics. This data is not needed to perform technical analysis.
  • A Product – students assuming the role of an expert should be required to produce individual reports that can be evaluated.
  • Additional Data – After a student has produced an opinion, a compelling piece of information should be introduced to the role-player in an effort to challenge their confidence in the rendered opinion.
  • Ethical Standards – a professional organization has ethical guidelines for member’s behavior. These codes of ethics can be obtained from organizations like the National Society of Professional Engineers.
  • Incentive Structure – What prize, or perceived benefit exists for the students to want to do a good job and satisfy the person pressuring them regarding the ethical challenge.
  • Feedback – A session or discussion regarding the experience should use to help students who participated in the role-play scenario make sense of the experience and understand the value of the exercise.

Using these concepts, instructors with a passion for teaching engineering ethics can be highly effective in their educational efforts.
